metadata.case_name: Contestants under Court Sale v. Widow and Daughter of Denis (Heirs of Severina Sabina Brito)

facts.text: Testatrix Mrs. Mary Magdelene Coelho was an Indian Christian lady of the Roman Catholic faith, a widow, possessed of considerable properties.
Testatrix had previously executed settlements in favour of her children.
Will executed by testatrix on July 25, 1907, in Canarese language, relating to properties remaining after settlements.
At date of will, testatrix had two daughters alive: eldest Severina Sabina Brito (also referred to as Severina Sobina Coelho), second Mary Matilda Coelho.
Third daughter died before 1907 leaving no issue.
Fourth daughter deceased, leaving granddaughter Juli Mary Margaret Fernandez (also Julia Mary Margenta Fernandez).
Severina had four sons, including Denis.

Clause 3(c) of will: 'All kinds of movable properties that shall be in my possession... all these my eldest daughter Severina Sobina Coelho, shall after my death, enjoy and after her lifetime, her male children also shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right.' Covers specified immovable properties and all movables at death.

Clause 4: Bagaitu hithlu land etc. to second daughter Mary Matilda Coelho to enjoy up to her death only, no alienation; after her, to granddaughter Julia hereditarily with permanent right; Julia's father and heirs no right; if Julia no marry or no issue, to Severina and her male descendants permanently.

Suit for partition and separate possession filed in September 1946 by widow and daughter of Denis (son of Severina) relating to property measuring 1 acre 37 cents with houses, part of property covered by cl. 3(c). Plaintiffs claim Severina had only life interest, remainder to male issues.
Defendants (appellants): Claim under purchaser in Court sale in execution of decree against Severina; contend Severina had absolute interest, so her full interest passed in auction.
Trial judge and District Judge upheld defendants' construction (absolute interest), dismissed suit.
Madras High Court single judge reversed, held Severina had life interest, decreed suit.
Numerous prior proceedings between parties; several parties died, legal representatives added.

Dispute over translation of cl. 3(c): Official translation has 'enjoy' twice; trial judge: 'after me my eldest daughter S. S. Coelho and after her lifetime her male children also with permanent and full rights shall enjoy.' High Court: 'shall after me be enjoyed by my eldest daughter Severina Sabina and after her lifetime by her male children too as permanent and absolute hukdars.'

legal_issues.text: Whether under cl. 3(c) of the will, the eldest daughter Severina took an absolute interest or merely a life interest with absolute remainder vesting in her male issues.

petitioner_arguments.text: Bequest to Severina is absolute under s.82 Indian Succession Act 1865; no contrary intention; 'enjoy permanently and with absolute rights' confers absolute interest; subsequent words to male children void as repugnant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Succession Act 1865 s.82, s.84 and illustrations

petitioner_arguments.text: Contrast with cl.4 which explicitly limits to 'up to her death only' and prohibits alienation; absence in cl.3(c) shows absolute interest.
Translation shows 'enjoy' once, qualifying both Severina and male children as permanent and absolute.
Male children not direct objects of independent gift under s.84; words of limitation, not purchase.

respondent_arguments.text: Severina took only life interest; words 'after her lifetime' create successive interests, remainder absolute to male children.

court_reasoning.text: Governed by Indian Succession Act 1865 (re-enacted 1925); general rules: construe from entire will, no part rejected if reasonable meaning, same words same sense.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption under s.82 for whole interest unless restricted; s.84 where words added describing class not direct gift.

court_reasoning.text: Translation analysis: 'enjoy' for Severina, then after lifetime male children enjoy permanently absolute; contrast in phraseology shows Severina's interest different (life).
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court translation nearer original; 'too/also' does not extend absolute to Severina.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'after her lifetime' make male children successive takers (s.84 ill. c), not joint; words of purchase, not limitation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Severina life interest to give effect to all dispositions.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.4 and cl.5 show 'after lifetime/death' indicate life interest, even without alienation prohibition.
Cardinal principle: give effect to every disposition if possible; absolute for Severina would void gift to male children, repugnant; cut down to life interest to validate remainder.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words after lifetime crucial for succession.

holdings.text: Under cl.3(c), Severina acquired only a life interest; absolute remainder to her male issues.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act, 1865
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules for construction of wills: presumption of absolute interest unless restricted (s.82); words describing class not direct gift denote whole interest unless contrary (s.84); illustrations applied to hold life interest with remainder.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Madras High Court judgment, holding Severina had life interest under cl.3(c); absolute remainder to male children; suit for partition decreed in favor of plaintiffs.
outcome.relief_granted: Partition and separate possession to plaintiffs as per High Court decree.

key_quotes.text: "All kinds of movable properties... my eldest daughter Severina Sobina Coelho, shall after my death, enjoy and after her lifetime, her male children also shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of disputed cl.3(c) central to interpretation.

key_quotes.text: "the interest created in favour of Severina was merely a life interest and that the remainder in absolute was conferred on her male children."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "to the extent that it is legally possible effect should be given to every disposition contained in the will."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle justifying cutting down absolute to life interest.
